overview: If you are responsible for at least one child, you may be eligible for Child Tax Credit - what you might get, how to claim, information if your child is disabled
title: Child Tax Credit

table.body:
You could qualify for Child Tax Credit if you are responsible for at least one child or young person who normally lives with you. These are payments made to the person who is mainly responsible for the child or children. 

##Who can claim
You can usually claim for:

* any child living with you - until 31 August after their 16th birthday
* young people under 20, if they're in [certain types of education or training](/child-tax-credit-when-child-reaches-16/approved-training-courses "Approved training courses")

^Check if you qualify - use this quick [online questionnaire.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/tools/taxcredits_qualify/question01.htm/ "Online questionnaire - do you qualify for tax credits?"){:rel="external"}^

##What you could get
To find out what you could get, use the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) [tax credits calculator](/tax-credits-calculator "Tax credits calculator").  

##Backdating your claim
Claims can normally be backdated by 3 months, check [backdating your tax credits claim](/backdating-your-tax-credits-claim "Backdating your tax credits claim") to see if it will be done automatically or if you need to let the Tax Credit Office know. 

##How to claim
Check if you are also eligible for [Working Tax Credit](/working-tax-credit "Working Tax Credit")  as you can claim both using the same [form](/claim-tax-credits/how-to-claim "Claim tax credits"). 

If you are already getting Working Tax Credit, call the [Tax Credit Helpline](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the Tax Credit Office") to update your claim.  

##Elements of Child Tax Credit
The table below shows the Child Tax Credit elements you could get and the maximum yearly payments. 

The payments apply whether or not you work. 

Elements | What it is | Max yearly amount
- | -
family (basic) element | basic payment if you qualify for Child Tax Credit | £545
child | paid on top of basic element for each of your children | £2,555
disabled child | for each disabled child | £2,800
severely disabled child | paid on top of disabled child element for each severely disabled child | £1,130

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
If your child has a disability you may qualify for extra Child Tax Credit.

##Who is eligible?
You qualify if any of the following apply:

- Disability Living Allowance is paid for your child
- your child is registered blind
- your child came off the blind register in the 28 weeks before you claimed tax credits

You can still qualify if the Disability Living Allowance stops because your child goes into hospital.

If the Highest Rate Care Component of Disability Living Allowance is paid for your child, you may get an additional payment for their severe disability.

##What you'll get
The amount of you get depends on your income and how much care your child needs. 

You could get up to **approximately**:

Your child is disabled | £53 a week | £2,800 a year
Your child is severely disabled | £75 a week | £3,930 a year

To find out what tax credits you could get overall, use the [online calculator.](/tax-credits-calculator "tax credits calculator")

##How to claim
If you are **not** currently getting tax credits, you need to [fill in a claim form](/claim-tax-credits/how-to-claim "Claim tax credits"). You can't apply online. 

If you are **already getting** tax credits, call the [Tax Credit Helpline](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the tax credit office") to amend your claim. You should do this as soon as you know that Disability Living Allowance (or the Highest Rate Care Component) will be paid for your child. 

^Contact the helpline within 3 months to get your [payments backdated](/backdating-your-tax-credits-claim "Backdating your tax credits claim").^
table.title: Your child is disabled

table.body:
You can claim if you're not getting any money from your:

* local authority
* Health and Social Services Board

If you are getting money from either of these, call the [Tax Credit Helpline](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the tax credit office") to find out if you can claim.
table.title: Adoptive or foster parents

table.body:
You can claim Child Tax Credit if you have responsibility for a child. For example, this could be if:

* the child usually lives with you
* the child keeps their toys, clothes and other items at your home
* you pay for their meals and give them pocket money

There can be exceptions to this, for example, if a child from abroad lives with you as an exchange student. 

If you're not sure whether you count as being responsible for a child you can call the [Tax Credit Helpline](/contact-the-tax-credit-office "Contact the tax credit office") for advice.
table.title: You’re not the child’s parent

table.body:
Only one household can get Child Tax Credit for a child.

If your child lives with more than one person you'll have to decide who should get it.

^You can't claim Child Tax Credit if your child doesn't live with you at all - even if you're paying maintenance.^

###You can’t agree who’ll claim
If you can't agree who'll get the Child Tax Credit, both of you should claim for the child. The Tax Credit Office will then decide for you. They'll contact both of you to work out who has main responsibility for the child. They will consider things that include the number of days the child lives with you, and where they keep most of their clothes and toys.

###You're already getting tax credits for your child
Someone else might make a claim for a child you're getting Child Tax Credit for. If this happens, the Tax Credit Office may ask you to tell them why you think you have main responsibility for that child.
table.title: Your child lives with more than one person
